to Maria Edgeworth, , Feby.February 13. 1827

div.p:
I suppose it is in vain to look for
the smallest belief in saying what nevertheless is the fact
that whether any Irish Mails have been robbed by the
Pro-Catholic party within the last three weeks or not, I have
never received up to this hour the letter of which you
make mention in the note to Sophia of yesterday evening
I fancy however that I sufficiently comprehend its drift
and have to answer that I know of London Booksellers only
three - Murray, Cadell (& Davies) & Mr Rees of the house of
Longman & that I shall be most happy in introducing
any friend of yours to any or all of them. Longmans & Co
are the great house for publishing Educational books
- it is their favourite business I believe; & probably
it is of all the most lucrative. Murray has some
books of the class & may have been highly successful
& he is I know very desirous to have more . of my good
friend
Mr Cadell's concerns I have no very accurate notion.
but suspect that house has got out of date except for
an Episcopal charge or a new Commentary on the
Apocalypse or a reprint of Johnson's dictionary
or the like.

Either Murray or Longman will I am sure be glad
of a good book for young people; & this is I doubt not
a good one - in short there is no difficulty in the
case. It is very different from

A virgin tragedy an orphan Muse -
are we to have no more charming Lucys &
Harries & Franks of your own?

My wife & boys (for there are 2 of them now)
are well - Johnny certainly much better in his
general health & at least no worse in his
local complaint.

Sir Walter Scott was in capital spirits
when with us a few weeks ago & so he is now but
for rheumatism that makes him occasionally grumble
Not being able to stir about with this companion he has
been working hard - as witness 6 vols of Napoleon
now on the table, & another or I suppose now others
nearly ready: to say nothing of the Chronicles of the
Canongate which is a Miscellany of little Tales he says
& with which he himself seems to be particularly pleased

A I beg to be remembered to Mrs Edgeworth, Mr G. L
to your family at Edgeworthstown - I hope Mr &
M rs
Butler are well and well pleased with wedlock.
div.closer:
Believe
me ever most truly & faithfully yours
J G Lockhart
Wimbledon, Surrey
Feby. February 13. 1827.
